Comparison between the shift from rule-based expert systems to modern AI approaches, as depicted in the provided corpus:

Rule-Based Expert Systems (1970s - early 1980s) [2]
1. Definition and emergence: Expert systems were one of the earlier research fields in Artificial Intelligence (AI), emerging around mid-1970s, as defined knowledge-intensive software systems designed to solve specific domain problems [2]. They behaved as artificial advisory systems for a particular problem domain [2]. 2. Structure: Expert systems contained specialized knowledge elicited from a domain expert [2]. The reasoning process was determined by the human expert [2]. These systems were initially built using classical expert system shells [2]. 3. Popularity and applications: After moving out of research laboratories during early 1980s, expert systems became more popular and found several application fields such as engineering, chemistry, medicine, industry, and many others [2]. 4. Knowledge engineering: The construction process of expert systems with specialized domain knowledge is defined as knowledge engineering [2]. Knowledge was acquired from periodicals, books, or through interviews with human experts [2]. Transition to Modern Approaches (1980s - Present) [1], [3], [4]
1. Shift in approaches: The recent wave of work on Bayesian networks and other statistical models has moved away from strictly rule-based systems towards more adaptable solutions for Natural Language Generation (NLG) systems [1]. These statistical methods aimed to be more flexible across different domains compared to rule-based systems [1]. 2. Hidden Markov Models: Hidden Markov Models (HMM) have featured prominently in integrating statistical models with NLG systems, albeit past work has also included other models [1]. 3. Uncertainty management: While much of human knowledge is uncertain, the field of artificial intelligence started focusing on the representation and management of uncertainty in rule-based reasoning from the late 1980s [4]. This focus eventually led to more general approaches in system design [4].
